mainContent.text:
2.3 Archetypes in Literature

        Completion requirements
        



Not Stereotypes, but Archetypes
Literary critic Joseph Campbell, in his book The Hero Has a Thousand Faces, says that all cultures, throughout time and place, have told the same story, using the same characters, time and again, over and over.  This recurring story he calls
    a "monomyth," (literally, "one age-old story").  These recurring characters are called archetypes, or stock characters who function in the same roles.  Even the plots of most epics, myths, romances, tragedies,
    and comedies follow the same patterns.   It's what Campbell calls "The Hero's Journey."
For example, what do Harry Potter, Simba, Luke Skywalker, Batman, and Cinderella all have in common?  They are all lonely orphans who become unlikely heroes!
What do the duos Hermione and Ron, Pumba and Timon, R2D2 and C3PO, Robin and Alfred, and the friendly animals from Cinderella all have in common?  They are socially awkward allies who support their respective heroes!
What about American Born Chinese?  What do the Monkey King, Jin Wang, and Danny all have in common?  Are they not ashamed, at one point, of their identity and cultural heritage?  Who are their allies?  Don't Tze-Yo-Tzuh
    and Wong Lai-Tasao help the Monkey King?  Don't Jing-Wei and Greg support Jin Wang?  Don't Chin-Kee and Melanie help Danny?  You see the patterns?
Take a look at the following discussion on archetypes to see if you can find any more connections...
Assignment:  
Read "The 12 Character Archetypes" 


Watch the following videos to learn more:




Reading:
Which Archetype are You?

Not Stereotypes, but Archetypes
